Dearest Parents . I have today received your letters of Aug 16
+ 17. I may mention that it's extremely trying to be told by
both of you that there's an impertinent article about me in the
New York Herald + not to know what it says. One imagines it to
be much worse (let's hope) that it is. I never heard of John
McHugh Stewart , damn him at a venture. Otherwise all
your news is pleasant + I'm glad you take an interest in
my letters, bless you. It's not at all true that I've determined
the fortunes of Iraq ( Mother ) but it is true that with an
Arab
Govt Government
I've come to my own. It's a delicate position to be so
much in their confidence. I'm very careful about not obtruding
myself on them. I let all the "come hither" emanate from them.
When they want to come + ask my advice I'm always there;
when they're busy with other things I go about with affairs
of my own. And then they all turn up breathlessly to tell
me their life + times! They haven't got an easy row to
hoe. They're so dreadfully anxious to conciliate their
own extremists who are, I privately think + openly tell them,
no better than poles clothed in tablecloths with a turnip on
top. Perhaps they'll find that out themselves in time + even
learn a little from my mockery of them. But the truth is
(+ they uneasily know it) that there's very little real
patriotism in this country + won't be till they people see that
the Arab
Govt Government
, with us behind it , isn't going to come
to grief. Meantime there's a considerable floating
population of asses who conceive that they'll either
manage the show or overturn it. They can do neither; I
don't care whether they learn it or not, for they are
quite unimportant, but I eagerly want the others to learn it
that they are unimportant.
Last Tuesday was the 15th of
Muharram First month of the Islamic calendar
, the 'Ashurah.
It's the culminating day of mourning for Husain , the anniversary
of his death. I went out to see the functions at

Kadhimain - you can't really see them for they take place
inside the mosque, but the Mayor of Kadhimain had prepared
for us a room in an empty house facing the mosque, where
we sat + watched the hoofs of the horses, Mr Garbett + I +
various other people from our office. Mr Garbett + I motored
out at 5.30 + found all the others there. It was a very nice
old Persian house with
latticed laticed
windows, belonging to someone
in Najaf . Soon after we arrived, Faisal drove by + went
into the mosque where he had a sort of box in the
courtyard + watched the Muharram play which we
could not see of course. They enact the whole history of
Husain 's death, the attack of Mu'awiyah 's hosts, the
little band killed one by one, the burning of their tents + the
cutting off of the heads of the dead to send to Mu'awiyah.
But before the play began there was procession after
procession, passing in + out under our windows. There were
the
Fidai Arabic term used to refer to various military groups willing to sacrifice themselves for a larger campaign.
of Husain. They were of two kinds, the comparatively
innocuous breast-beaters, + the men who cut themselves
with swords. In Turkish times, when they were allowed to
do as they chose, a number of the latter killed themselves;
now it is all regulated by the police + though it looks
horrible it isn't dangerous. The process is as follows: having
carefully shaved your hair so as to leave bare a long
narrow strip of your head, like an
exaggerated parting, an inspector of police then makes
several gashes in your scalp with a sword. They bleed
like anything; the blood runs all down your face + by
patting your head with your hands + then applying these
to your white cotton robe you make a stupendous appearance
of goriness. Some of them had the whole of their robes at the
back completely drenched in blood, but I can't help
thinking it must have been someone else's blood, a sheep's
perhaps. At the same time I'm bound to say that

+ several of them looked very much overcome, staggering along
supported by their colleagues, + one had to be carried
away bodily. They all rushed out of the mosque
brandishing swords + knives, but these were most skilfully
removed from them, often under protest
, by the
inspector of police who had dealt the original slashes,
so that they couldn't, in a fit of enthusiasm, do themselves
any further harm. It's all extraordinarily savage +
the Sunnis hate it, thinking it a disgrace to Islam.
So, in a way, it is.
After these gentry had finished their antics nothing
happened for a long long time - it isn't at all well
stage-managed, the entr'acts are too prolonged. Notwithstanding
the great interest of the crowd - they were amazing,
every sort of person,

tribesmen, gentlemen in
European suits, soldiers, police, Faisal 's body guard,
+ human kind of every sort - I lay down on the floor +
went soundly to sleep for half an hour. About noon
Saiyid Ja'far (the Mayor) announced that lunch
was ready as his house. We went down into a little
side street where spectators + gaudily dressed actors were
lying about in the wings, so to speak. While I was
waiting for the others to come I talked to the actors,
asked them which army they belonged to + got eager
rejoinders - you'll bear in mind that before the war
no European had been allowed wither sight of
Kadhiman on the 'Ashurah - Then, Saiyid Ja'far leading,
we walked through the streets past two of the gates of
the mosque, + down the narrow lane to his house. The
people were resting wherever there was shade; sellers
of bread + haricot beans + water were busily

plying their trade. I said "'Awafi - your health!" + they
all replied. "Two healths, two healths! do you hear
what she says? She says 'Awafi! God give you
health, God give you health!" Some, as they saw
Saiyid Ja'far got up + saluted him: "Peace upon you,
Saiyid!". As he stood fumbling at the door of his
house with a huge key, I suddenly had a vivid
sense of the strangeness + familiarity of it all - the
Saiyid in his green robe a turban + the
hot
narrow street, + the people who ought to have been
by rights fanatically enraged at our presence +
somehow weren't.
Personally I'm a Sunni but it's no good pretending
that I don't feel just as near to an old party like
Saiyid Ja'far or a
Shi'ah An Islamic sect who believe that the descendants of the Prophet Muhammad are the rightful leaders of Islam.
tribesman eating haricot beans.
We did have a good lunch!
When we got back to one window the play in the
mosque court was nearly over + presently all the actors
came streaming out, led horses, richly hung with brocades,
the palanquins of the women (inhabited by little boys
+ girls who were largely delighted at taking a
part in the performance) banners + banners, +
banners, mostly black, or else the Persian flag,
+ extremely realistic bloody corpses carried on biers.
Then Faisal came out + drove away, + presently we
left, found our motors in a side street + came
home. It was 2 o'clock by that time.
They go on reading what you may term masses for Husain
for the rest of the month of
Muharram First month of the Islamic calendar.
. Faisal has paid for
a nightly mass of this sort at Kadhimain + has several
attended himself. He is, you know, a Sunni but

3 he is busy conciliating the
Shi'ahs An Islamic sect who believe that the descendants of the Prophet Muhammad are the rightful leaders of Islam.
, + after all Husain is his
direct ancestor. I am not at all sure, however, that he gains
much by it. The Sunnis pull rather wry faces over it
- no Turkish wali would have gone near one of these
functions for the Sunnis think them idolatry. On the
other hand the sort of Shi'ahs Faisal wants to conciliate,
the 'alim class, think it's mere diplomacy on his part
+ the fact remains that the happy hunting ground of
Turkish emissaries is this very lot of sanctimonious rogues.
Having shouted against the Turks all their days, they now
find they are not getting what they expected out
of the Arab
Govt Government
+ they are ready to lend an ear to
the Turks. The Turks in the old days found their shouting
to be mere sound + fury, + I think myself that if the
Arab
Govt Government
stands up to them it will find they have
no more significance than before. It's the eternal struggle
with the clerical who wishes to usurp the functions of the
civil administration if you'll let him. And if you do let
him you become like Spain , or Papal Italy - a dry stick
that breaks over the back of the enemy you want to beat.
Very interesting developments are taking place is Kurdistan .
From the moment Faisal arrived he began to have messages
+ letters from the Kurdish magnates north of our frontier
saying they wanted to throw off the Turkish yoke + make
an autonomous Kurdistan with Faisal as King (a sort of
Austria-Hungary, absit omen !) under Brinish protection.
Now they are asking him to summon to Baghdad a
conference of Kurdish leaders, some of whom are in
Paris + some in Constantinople . Faisal keeps us fully
informed but if he didn't it would not matter for
the emissaries always come + tell me what is in the

letters, often before they deliver them to him. Faisal
naturally wants to know what
H.M.G. His Majesty's Government
's policy is - a
thing
H.M.G. His Majesty's Government
, between ourselves, doesn't know itself. The
matter is complicated by the facts (1) that no two
Kurds ever agree when it comes to practice (2)
that part of the area which they propose to form into
a Kurdish state under British protection are in the
French zone. The Kurds under no circumstances whatever
will have anything to do with the French + I don't
see how the French can force them, even when
they are in their zone, to stand out of the Kurdish
state. We have been able to split up the Arabs into two
separate countries but both of them were occupied by French +
British troops. That is not the case with Kurdistan . The French
are not in military occupation of any part of their zone there
nor is it within the bounds of possibility that they ever will be.
Who, therefore, is to coerce the inhabitants if they refuse to fall
in with artificial lines of demarcation agreed upon in
London or Paris ?
I had an Arab dinner party of not important people -
A nice little Christian, Yusuf Ghanimah who is secretary
of the Salam public library of which I'm President; the
editor of one of the local papers, 'Abdul Latif Fallahi ,
an empty creature; a very nice army doctor, Ma'luf (Arab
army) + a charming + simple Syrian, Hasan Wifki . It
wasn't a very amusing evening.
Sep
September
. 18. Sunday. I've been out all day with the Coxes ,
the rest of the party being
Capt. Captain
Cheesman (
H.E.' His Excellency
s private
secretary, a very dear creature + a great naturalist) +
Major Wilkinson of the Wireless, who is a great friend of
the Coxes + me. We left about 9.30 by launch, went
up river, stopping on the way for the men to shoot,

4. lunched on the launch + then got off at a place called
Fahamah where there's an empty house to which we often
go for picnics in the autumn. Sir Percy + I + the other
men walked through the orange gardens + palm gardens out
into the desert; they got various little birds for the collection
Sir Percy + Capt Cheesman are making. The palm
gardens are a vision of beauty. The date gathering is just
beginning but yet the great golden branches crown the trees.
They look like huge splendid crown imperials.
The thing to notice is that for the first time we were
able to be out all day. The temperature has made
a great drop this week - it has been as low as a
maximum of 99°. Yesterday when I got into my
office I felt quite shivery + looking at the thermometer
I fond it was 80°. That's shivering point here.
We did not get in this evening till past 8 o'clock +
I've just dined + am feeling very sleepy. So goodnight.
Your affectionate daughter
Gertrude.
